A metal–free porous organic polymer with high CO2 adsorption for robust aqueous CO2 photoreduction via molecular regulation Xinyue Hong Data curation Investigation Methodology Youting Fang Validation Investigation Duobin Chao Supervision Writing – original draft Funding acquisition ⁎ School of Materials Science and Chemical Engineering, Ningbo University, Ningbo, Zhejiang 315211, China School of Materials Science and Chemical Engineering Ningbo University Ningbo Zhejiang 315211 China School of Materials Science and Chemical Engineering, Ningbo University, Ningbo, Zhejiang 315211, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Development of photocatalysts with both high CO2 adsorption capacity and robust CO2 reduction performance is promising toward carbon capture and utilization (CCU). Herein, a porous organic polymer (POP) based on molecular monomers 1,2,3,5–Tetrakis(carbazol–9–yl)–4,6–dicyanobenzene (4CzIPN) and 9–(4–([2,2′:6′,2′'–terpyridin]–4′–yl)phenyl)–9H–carbazole (CzTPY) has been prepared for metal–free photocatalytic reduction of CO2 to CO with 94.7% selectivity in 100% aqueous medium. The POP displays a yield of CO up to 265.7 mmol g–1, which is among the highest yields for POPs–based photocatalytic systems. More importantly, the POP also shows a high CO2 uptake of 109.1 cm3 g–1 (21.4 wt%) at 273 K and 1 atm. External photosensitizers or catalysts are not required in this photocatalytic system. Mechanistic studies indicate the introduction of CzTPY improved the electron transfer and charge separation. These results show a feasible way to construct POP–based photocatalysts not only capturing CO2 efficiently but also catalyzing CO2 reduction with a high yield by rational regulation of molecular monomers. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Porous organic polymer CO2 reduction CO2 adsorption Photocatalysis Metal–free Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction As greenhouse gasses (e.g., CO2) emissions increase, global warming occurs and strategies for carbon capture and utilization (CCU) are widely investigated to mitigate the climate crisis [1]. CCU is usually established by using amine–based solvents to absorb CO2 which is then released through a desorption process for further utilization [2]. However, the multistep process through adsorption, desorption, and final utilization of CO2 could consume a lot of energy. It is necessary to develop a sustainable system that shows high CO2 adsorption capacity and can directly convert CO2 to value–added chemicals with low energy consumption. In this context, light–driven reduction of CO2 to chemicals and fuels (CO, HCOOH, CH4, etc.) using abandon solar energy seems to be a promising method [3,4]. Up to now, numerous photocatalytic systems have been developed for CO2 reduction with a variety of photocatalysts such as molecular metal complexes, inorganic semiconductors, organic semiconductors, and their hybrid materials [5,6]. However, photocatalysts rarely exhibit a high CO2 uptake. It is envisioned that photocatalysts bearing high CO2 adsorption would show superior catalytic performance and benefit CCU with more simplified process. Porous organic polymers (POPs), emerging as a class of powerful porous materials in many research fields such as sensors [7], photocatalytic organic transformations [8], water treatment [9], batteries [10], cancer theranostics [11], and biomedical applications [12,13], have also gained considerable attention as efficient catalysts in CO2 photoreduction, due to their tunable band gaps, versatile building blocks, visible–light absorption capability, and large specific surface areas [14,15]. POPs for CO2 photoreduction could be mainly divided into three categories including POPs loaded with metals, metal–free POPs, and POPs requiring external photosensitizers [16–19]. Metal–embedded POPs are mostly studied for CO2 photoreduction. For example, donor–π–acceptor porous organic polymers were used for CO2 photoreduction after coordination to cobalt(II) cations [20,21]. The cobalt(II) cations served as catalytic sites to reduce CO2. However, metal–free POPs for light–driven reduction of CO2 have been less developed, probably owing to fewer organic active sites than metal–based catalytic sites [15,18,22]. Metal–free POPs are suitable for cost–effective catalysis toward CO2 conversion [15]. Beside, organic solvents were usually indispensable to achieve efficient CO2 photoreduction. Although water as a green solvent is promising for CO2 photoreduction, rare photocatalysts could display robust CO2 photoreduction in water [23,24]. A large amount of H2 could be generated simultaneously due to competitive H2O reduction in 100% aqueous medium, resulting in a relatively low selectivity. It is still challenging to develop highly efficient and selective CO2 photoreduction systems with suppressed H2O reduction in 100% aqueous medium. POPs are commonly synthesized by bottom–up coupling and condensation reactions of molecular building monomers [8]. Thus, molecular monomers have significant effects on intrinsic properties of POPs such as light absorption wavelengths, chemical skeletons, CO2 adsorbed quantities, redox potentials, and electron transfer processes. In this context, regulating building monomers could be a feasible way to achieve highly efficient POPs in CO2 photoreduction. Although a lot of monomers have been used as building blocks for synthesizing POPs in CO2 photoreduction [15], a POP that can strongly capture CO2 and efficiently convert CO2 to value–added products with high selectivity and yield remains scarce, especially in 100% aqueous medium (Scheme 1 ). Compared to corresponding homogeneous photocatalysts for CO2 photoreduction, POP–based photocatalysts are also expected to be recyclable. In this work, we employed 1,2,3,5–Tetrakis(carbazol–9–yl)–4,6–dicyanobenzene (4CzIPN) and a carbazole derivative of terpyridine 9–(4–([2,2′:6′,2′'–terpyridin]–4′–yl)phenyl)–9H–carbazole (CzTPY) as molecular building monomers to construct two metal–free amorphous POPs for CO2 adsorption and photoreduction (Scheme 1). One is PolyIPN solely composed of 4CzIPN, and the other is PolyIPN–TPY which is regulated with CzTPY. Both two POPs are amorphous and active toward CO2 photoreduction in water medium without any organic solvent. It was found that PolyIPN–TPY was much more efficient than PolyIPN with an approximately 212–fold increase in the yield of CO. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials and instruments All reagents including solvents and starting materials for synthesis were purchased from commercial suppliers including Energy Chemical, aladdin and Macklin without further purification. CzTPY was synthesized as previously reported [25]. NMR spectra were recorded on Bruker 400 M. CVs were obtained on CHI660E in a one–compartment cell equipped with glassy carbon working electrode, Ag/AgCl reference electrode, and platinum plate counter electrode at room temperature. Photoelectrochemical measurements were carried out on CHI660E with FTO glass deposited POPs as working electrode, Ag/AgCl reference electrode, and platinum plate counter electrode. UV–vis–NIR absorption spectra were recorded on a G9 spectrophotometer. The potentials were referenced to SCE through an internal standard oxidation of ferrocene. GC analysis for CO2 reduction was performed on Shimadzu GC–2014 (packed column TDX–01, 2 m x 3 mm, FID detector with Shimadzu Methanizer MTN–1 for CO and TCD detector for H2, N2 as carrier gas). Liquid product such as HCOOH was analyzed by 1H NMR. Isotopic labeling product 13CO was characterized with Agilent 7890B–5977A. Powder X–ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained using D8 Advance Xray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation. X–ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out using Thermo Scientific K–Alpha with Al Kα X–ray source (hν = 1486.6 eV). Fourier transform infrared (FT–IR) spectra were obtained on a Nicolet 670 FT–IR spectrometer with KBr. Time–resolved emission decay curves were recorded on Edinburgh FLS1000 spectrometer. The UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS) were recorded on Lambda 950 Scan Spectrophotometers (Perkin Elmer). N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms were obtained with Micromeritics ASAP 2460 at 77 K. CO2 adsorption isotherm was obtained with Micromeritics ASAP 2460 at 273 K. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) images were obtained on a ZEISS Sigma 300 Field–Emission Scanning Electron Microscope. In situ DRIFT measurements were conducted on Bruker INVENIO spectrometer with a Harrick in situ diffuse reflectance cell. 2.2 Synthesis of PolyIPN–TPY To a glass reaction bottle equipped with a dropping funnel, FeCl3 (340.0 mg, 2.1 mmol) and CHCl3 (30.0 mL) were added to form a suspension. At the same time, CzTPY (100.0 mg, 0.21 mmol) and 4CzIPN (166.0 mg. 0.21 mmol) were dissolved in CHCl3 (30.0 mL) and added into the dropping funnel. Then the whole setup was degassed with N2. The suspension was stirred at 60 °C. The solution containing CzTPY and 4CzIPN in the dropping funnel was added dropwise into the suspension. After 24 h, CH3OH (20.0 mL) was added to the reaction suspension. Then, the suspension was filtered and the filter cake was washed three times with H2O, CH3OH and THF, respectively. The filter cake was collected and stirred three times (once for 12 h) in 20 mL mixed solution composed of CH3OH and concentrated HCl (v/v. 1:1) for 36 h. Next, the mixed solution was filtered and the filter cake was washed with H2O, CH3OH and THF three times. The filter cake was then transferred to a Soxhlet extractor and retracted with THF (60.0 mL) and CH3OH (60.0 mL) three times (once for 12 h), respectively. Finally, the residue in the Soxhlet extractor was collected and PolyIPN–TPY (213.0 mg, 80.1%) was obtained after dry at 80 °C in vacuum. 2.3 Synthesis of PolyIPN The synthetic procedure was similar to that for PolyIPN–TPY by using 4CzIPN (315.0 mg, 0.4 mmol) and PolyIPN was obtained as a powder (291.0 mg, 92.3%). 2.4 Photocatalytic CO2 reduction General procedure: PolyIPN (2.0 mg) or PolyIPN–TPY (2.0 mg) were added into water (5.0 mL) containing TEOA (300.0 mg) in a glass tube. The reaction suspension was sonicated for 30 min and then bubbled with CO2 for 16 min. Next, the glass tube was sealed up with a suited rubber plug for light irradiation. Light source is a white LED light equipment (SMPC–LVWT, 420–650 nm, 3 W LEDs) supplied by Technical Institute of Physics and Chemistry & Chinese Academy of Sciences. The gaseous products were analyzed by injection of 100 µL aliquots from headspace into GC2014 instrument equipped with TCD and FID detectors. Liquid products such as HCOOH were analyzed by 1H NMR. Isotopic labeling experiment was conducted with 13CO2 which was supplied by ISOTOPE. Estimation of photonic efficiency was based on the emitted photons with a blue light LEDs setup at 440 nm. 2.5 Photoelectrochemical measurements FTO glasses as the working electrode for photoelectrochemical measurements were prepared as follow: PolyIPN (5.0 mg) or PolyIPN–TPY (5.0 mg) were sonicated for 10 min to form a suspension in 5.0 mL CH3OH. Then, 10 μL Nafion was added to the suspension for another 10 min sonication. The suspension (200 μL) was carefully dropped onto the conductive surface of FTO glasses. Next, the FTO glass was dried under vacuum at 50 °C for 6 h to be used as the working electrode. Transient photocurrent responses and electrochemical impedance spectra were all obtained in the aqueous Na2SO4 solution (0.4 M) with a three–electrode electrochemical cell. The working electrode was FTO glass loaded with PolyIPN or PolyIPN–TPY. The reference electrode was Ag/AgCl and the counter electrode was platinum plate. For transient photocurrent responses, the whole run time was 300 s. The test started in the dark for 20 s and light was turned on for 20 s. The interval was controlled as 20 s. The light source was the white LEDs equipment that used for photocatalytic experiments. The open circuit potential was set as 0.4 V. For electrochemical impedance spectra, the open circuit potential was the same and the frequency was set from 0.1 to 105 Hz. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of PolyIPN and PolyIPN–TPY The oxidative coupling reactions were performed to obtain PolyIPN and PolyIPN–TPY as amorphous powders (Scheme 1). Both PolyIPN and PolyIPN–TPY are not soluble in common solvents such as water and chloroform. They were further characterized by various methods. Powder X–ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were firstly carried out to confirm amorphous feature of PolyIPN and PolyIPN–TPY. As shown in Fig. 1 a, broad peaks and no crystallinity were observed from the XRD patterns of PolyIPN and PolyIPN–TPY, while XRD patterns of molecular building monomers 4CzIPN and CzTPY exhibited good crystallinity (Fig. S1). This is consistent with reported similar polymerization reactions using carbazole–based monomers, which also resulted in amorphous POPs [26,27]. Nevertheless, the thermal stability of PolyIPN and PolyIPN–TPY was improved compared to building monomers by TGA results (Fig. S2). Additionally, PolyIPN–TPY lost less weight below 500 °C, indicating CzTPY in PolyIPN–TPY could enhance the thermal stability through the copolymerization reaction with 4CzIPN. The porosities of PolyIPN and PolyIPN–TPY were also studied by N2 adsorption–desorption experiments. As shown in Fig. 1b, the BET surface area and pore size of PolyIPN–TPY were found to be 160 m2 g–1 and 4.28 nm, respectively. PolyIPN displayed a larger BET surface area of 889 m2 g–1 and a smaller pore size of 3.73 nm (Fig. S3), suggesting CzTPY molecules were mainly embedded and distributed in the skeleton of PolyIPN. Although the surface area of PolyIPN–TPY was much smaller than PolyIPN, PolyIPN–TPY showed a higher CO2 uptake (Fig. 1c). The CO2 uptake of PolyIPN–TPY is 109.1 cm3 g–1 (21.4 wt %), which is outstanding among reported POPs in CO2 photoreduction [18,28,29]. The high CO2 uptake of PolyIPN–TPY is probably due to rich Lewis base N atoms which could enhance the affinity with electrophilic CO2 molecules [27]. PolyIPN without the terpyridine group showed a lower CO2 uptake of 89.7 cm3 g–1 (17.9 wt %), indicating the regulation of PolyIPN with molecular CzTPY is beneficial for improving the CO2 uptake of PolyIPN–TPY. The porous morphologies of PolyIPN and PolyIPN–TPY were further studied by SEM. The SEM image of PolyIPN showed a plate–like structure with small dispersed circular clusters (Fig. 1d), while PolyIPN–TPY exhibited a crosslinked vessel–like feature (Fig. 1e). This difference was probably because CzTPY increased the extent of crosslinking in PolyIPN–TPY. Fourier transform infrared spectrum (FT–IR) spectra of CzTPY, PolyIPN, and PolyIPN–TPY were all recorded. As shown in Fig. 1f, characterized wavenumbers of CzTPY and PolyIPN could be also observed in the FT–IR spectrum of PolyIPN–TPY. The wavenumbers at 3050, 791, and 738 cm–1 are assigned to C–H vibrations of phenyl groups in CzTPY, PolyIPN, and PolyIPN–TPY. The signal at 2230 cm–1 is not found in CzTPY but can be observed in both PolyIPN and PolyIPN–TPY due to CN stretching vibrations. The characterized signals of PolyIPN–TPY from 1220 to 1700 cm–1 is almost the sum of those of CzTPY and PolyIPN such as 1693, 1600, 1518, 1450, and 1227 cm–1 that are ascribed to pyridine and benzene rings. These results are in line with the synthetic process of PolyIPN–TPY by using 4CzIPN and CzTPY as the starting materials. Surface elements of PolyIPN and PolyIPN–TPY were studied by X–ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The survey spectra of PolyIPN and PolyIPN–TPY showed they both mainly contain elements such as C and N (Fig. S4). The signal of Fe 2p was not found from 700 to 740 eV. For example, the high resolution XPS spectrum of PolyIPN–TPY in the range of 700–740 eV showed no obvious peaks that should be ascribed to Fe 2p at approximately 708 and 721 eV (Fig. S5) [30]. Furthermore, iron element was also not detected for PolyIPN–TPY by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrum (ICP–OES). High resolution N 1s spectra of PolyIPN and PolyIPN–TPY are a bit different (Fig. 1g). For both PolyIPN and PolyIPN–TPY, the signal peaks at 400.6 and 399.4 eV were ascribed to N–(C)3 of carbazole groups and CN bonds in 4CzIPN fragments [31]. However, PolyIPN–TPY exhibited a signal peak at 398.6 eV that was assigned to C–N=C bonds of pyridine units, which is consistent with its building monomers including 4CzIPN and CzTPY [28]. It is reasonable that no such signal was observed in the N 1s spectrum of PolyIPN. Their high resolution C 1s spectra are similar (Fig. S6). UV–vis DRS spectra of PolyIPN and PolyIPN–TPY are shown in Fig. S7. They both exhibit good visible light absorption capability, indicating they could be directly used for visible light photocatalysis without addition of other light–absorbing photosensitizers. The spectrum of PolyIPN–TPY shows more stronger absorbance beyond 500 nm, which indicates regulating the skeleton of PolyIPN with molecular CzTPY increases response toward visible light for PolyIPN–TPY. The small absorption peak at 580 nm is attributed to terpyridine groups in PolyIPN–TPY as observed in the UV–vis DRS spectrum of terpyridine–modified mpg–C3N4 [32]. The chemical structure of PolyIPN–TPY was also studied by solid state CP/MAS 13C NMR spectrum. The 13C NMR spectrum is very broad from 90 to 155 ppm with four observable bands around 145.6, 137.3, 123.4, and 111.1 ppm (Fig. S8). However, other peaks are not completely excluded due to the overlay of chemical shifts. The signals at 137.3 and 145.6 ppm could be attributed to carbons near N atoms in carbazole and pyridine groups, respectively. The two peaks at 123.4 and 111.1 ppm are assigned to other carbons including cyan groups and unsubstituted phenyl carbons, respectively. These peaks are similar to those in reported carbazole–based POPs [26,27,31]. Although the solid 13C NMR spectrum is hard to distinguish all carbons clearly, it is helpful to characterize the general chemical structure of PolyIPN–TPY. 3.2 Photocatalytic CO2 reduction To evaluate the possibility of CzTPY as the active site of CO2 reduction, the cyclic voltammograms (CVs) of CzTPY were recorded under N2 and CO2 atmospheres, respectively. As shown in Fig. 2 a, a reversible redox process at –2.01 V vs. SCE was assigned to one–electron reduction of CzTPY to generate corresponding anion under the N2 atmosphere. However, this process turned to be irreversible under CO2 atmosphere. Additionally, the current started to increase at –1.76 V vs. SCE, indicating the probable catalytic behavior of CzTPY toward CO2 reduction. Our previous studies have shown that molecular 4CzIPN could sensitize bis(terpyridine)iron(II) complexes bearing high overpotentials at approximate –1.80 V vs. SCE for efficient CO2 photoreduction [33]. Therefore, the electron transfer from 4CzIPN to CzTPY is thermodynamically available under visible light irradiation. Additionally, the covalent linkage between 4CzIPN and CzTPY in the PolyIPN–TPY might be helpful for this process. Therefore, PolyIPN–TPY is likely to reduce CO2 without addition of external catalysts via the efficient cooperation between 4CzIPN and CzTPY unit in the PolyIPN–TPY. Considering the insolubility of PolyIPN and PolyIPN–TPY in common solvents and water as a green solvent, photocatalytic CO2 reduction experiments were carried out in water containing triethanolamine (TEOA) as the electron donor. The POPs PolyIPN and PolyIPN–TPY as heterogeneous catalysts were directly used for CO2 photoreduction without addition of other photosensitizers or catalysts. The control experiments under various conditions are shown in Table 1 . PolyIPN only generated a very small amount of CO (2.5 μmol) with negligible H2 formation after 24 h of visible light irradiation in the presence of TEOA (Entry 3). However, a much higher yield of CO was found to be 530.7 μmol when PolyIPN–TPY was used (Entry 1). Therefore, the photocatalytic performance remarkably increased by regulating PolyIPN with CzTPY, indicating the significance of CzTPY in the photocatalysis. After 24 h of visible light irradiation, the amount of H2 generation was found to be 29.6 μmol for PolyIPN–TPY, giving the 94.7% selectivity of CO over H2. The high selectivity of CO formation suggested H2 evolution was mostly suppressed even in the 100% aqueous solution. No liquid products were found by 1H NMR spectrum. However, molecular 4CzIPN showed no catalytic efficiency in water containing TEOA (Entry 5), suggesting the polymer structure was crucial for CO2 photoreduction. In the absence of TEOA, PolyIPN–TPY generated a very tiny amount of CO about 0.5 μmol (Entry 2), while no CO was found for PolyIPN under the same catalytic condition (Entry 4). This suggested that water could be also used as the electron donor for PolyIPN–TPY instead of PolyIPN. Although the catalytic efficiency without TEOA was negligible, PolyIPN–TPY was still more powerful than PolyIPN. Light was found to be indispensable for efficient CO2 reduction with PolyIPN–TPY (Entry 6). Further isotopic labeling experiment with 13CO2 confirmed catalytic reduction of CO2 to CO (Fig. S9). Fig. 2b presents the time–dependent CO evolution using PolyIPN–TPY and PolyIPN under 24 h of visible light irradiation. For PolyIPN, the yield of CO was relatively low as 1.26 mmol g–1, indicating PolyIPN was not a highly efficient photocatalyst in CO2 photoreduction. For PolyIPN–TPY, the amount of CO increased almost linearly and finally gained an approximately 212–fold increase of CO yield as 265.7 mmol g–1 and only a small amount of H2 (94.7% selectivity). The photonic efficiency of CO formation was estimated to be 1.2%. Additionally, PolyIPN–TPY showed a relatively good recyclability during photocatalysis and could be reused as photocatalysts without significant loss of activity at least four times (Fig. 2c). It is noteworthy that the yield of CO formation is not linearly related to the mass of PolyIPN–TPY used in the photocatalytic reaction (Fig. 2b and 2c), because only limited catalytic sites are involved in the catalysis at the same time. After the recyclable experiments, the XRD patterns of PolyIPN–TPY were recorded and indicated PolyIPN–TPY was still amorphous after photocatalysis (Fig. S10). The XPS spectra after photocatalysis were similar to those before photocatalysis (Fig. S11), indicating the good stability of PolyIPN–TPY. Although PolyIPN–TPY showed a good stability in water medium, it should be noted that its catalytic performance will finally decrease in the much longer time irradiation, which is reasonable and normally caused by the degradation of monomers for POP–based photocatalysts. This can be assumed by the FT–IR spectrum after photocatalysis (Fig. 2d). After the photocatalysis, the FT–IR spectra of PolyIPN–TPY only changed a little and maintained the basic signals. Nevertheless, PolyIPN–TPY still displayed considerable advantages in CO2 photoreduction such as metal–free, water–tolerant, high CO2 uptake, high yield of product, and high selectivity. In comparison with other relevant studies, CO yield in this work is still outstanding [22,28,29,34–38]. More importantly, most of POPs photocatalysts are metal–based and used in the presence of organic solvents such as acetonitrile. The robust performance of PolyIPN–TPY is supposed to originate from the efficient cooperation between 4CzIPN and CzTPY in the skeleton of PolyIPN–TPY, as well as the high uptake of CO2. 3.3 Mechanistic studies The cooperation between 4CzIPN and CzTPY in PolyIPN–TPY was further investigated by photoelectrochemical measurements and photoluminescence spectroscopy. As can be seen from Fig. 3 a, the current obviously increased for both PolyIPN–TPY and PolyIPN when the light irradiation was turned on, while much lower current was observed for them in the dark. Therefore, light irradiation was vital for efficient charge separation, which was in agreement with the reduction of CO2 driven by light. Additionally, PolyIPN–TPY displayed much stronger photocurrent response than PolyIPN, indicating the regulation of PolyIPN with CzTPY enhanced the migration of photoinduced charge carriers such as electrons in PolyIPN–TPY. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) tests showed the lower charge transfer resistance in PolyIPN–TPY than that in PolyIPN (Fig. 3b), indicating the photoinduced electron transfer was more efficient in PolyIPN–TPY than PolyIPN. This is probably due to conjugated structure and electron–accepting capacity of redox–active terpyridine group in PolyIPN–TPY which could be seemed as an electron reservoir during photocatalysis. The steady state photoluminescence spectra of PolyIPN and PolyIPN–TPY showed similar emission bands at 532 nm which could be ascribed to the emission of monomer 4CzIPN in both POPs (Fig. S12) [39]. But, the emission intensity of PolyIPN was higher than that of PolyIPN–TPY, indicating the emission quenching of 4CzIPN by CzTPY in PolyIPN–TPY as a result of photoinduced electron transfer from 4CzIPN to CzTPY. The time–resolved photoluminescence spectra of PolyIPN–TPY and PolyIPN were also recorded at 532 nm (Fig. 3c). It was found that the CzTPY–regulated PolyIPN–TPY exhibited a shorter emission lifetime of 1.09 ns than that of PolyIPN (2.21 ns), which further evidenced the efficient photoinduced electron transfer between 4CzIPN and CzTPY. These results demonstrated that the electron transfer and charge separation became more efficient in PolyIPN–TPY after the introduction of CzTPY. To know more about the probable intermediates during photocatalysis, in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transformation spectroscopy (DRIFTS) experiments were carried out with PolyIPN–TPY in the presence of water and CO2 under visible light irradiation. As shown in Fig. 3d, signal peaks are mostly assigned to carbonate (CO3 2–), bicarbonate (HCO3 –), COOH*, and CO* by comparison with previous studies [18,34,40–44]. For example, the peaks at 1448, 1582, and 1624 cm–1 are probably due to monodentate carbonate m–CO3 2– and the peaks at 1320 and 1468 cm–1 are ascribed to bidentate carbonate b–CO3 2–. The bicarbonate species HCO3 – probably exhibits peaks at 1270, 1414, and 1701 cm–1. These species are in line with the experimental conditions containing CO2 and H2O. Peaks at 1389, 1546, and 1565 cm–1 could be probably attributed to appearance of adsorbed species COOH*. The peak at 2068 cm–1 showed the existence of adsorbed CO* [45]. These results demonstrated the uptake of CO2 by PolyIPN–TPY in water and intermediates such as COOH* during photocatalysis. Inspired by the above results, a probable mechanism for CO2 photoreduction with PolyIPN–TPY was proposed. As shown in Fig. 4 , CO2 gas molecules could be adsorbed by PolyIPN–TPY due to the high uptake of CO2 (step 1). Then, upon visible light irradiation, 4CzIPN unit could reach excited–state which is a moderate oxidant with a potential about +1.35 V vs. SCE [39]. As a result, 4CzIPN in PolyIPN–TPY could accept an electron from the electron donor TEOA whose potential is around +0.82 V vs. SCE [46]. The reduced 4CzIPN is powerful and capable of inducing the reduction of aryl halides [47]. Reduction of aryl halides normally needs powerful reductants [48]. We found 4CzIPN could reduce 1,4–dichlorobenzene to chlorobenzene under visible light irradiation in the presence of TEA (Fig. S13). The reduction potential of 1,4–dichlorobenzene was found to be –2.24 V vs. SCE (Fig. S14). Therefore, the electron in the reduced 4CzIPN with a more negative reduction potential about –2.24 V will transfer to CzTPY fragment (e.g., the reduction potential for CO2 reduction is –1.76 V) during photocatalysis. The CzTPY fragment is redox–active and could store an electron through its reduced state, resulting in more efficient separation of photogenerated charge carriers than pristine PolyIPN as proved by the above experimental results. The reduced CzTPY bearing an electron can interact with CO2 as shown in Fig. 2a. Since there are numerous CzTPY fragments in PolyIPN–TPY, the adsorbed CO2* will be facilely reduced to COOH* during photocatalysis. Water can serve as the proton source to induce the bond C–O breaking in COOH*, and then the intermediate COOH* is reduced to CO* with release of H2O [34,43]. Finally, CO gas escapes from the interaction with PolyIPN–TPY. This probable mechanism provides the molecular insight on the reaction process and highlights the significance of the redox–active CzTPY unit. 4 Conclusions In summary, a porous organic polymer (POP) PolyIPN–TPY has been prepared for highly efficient and selective photocatalytic CO2 reduction in 100% aqueous medium without external photosensitizers or catalysts. Compared to the pristine PolyIPN, PolyIPN–TPY exhibited a higher uptake of CO2 and more efficient separation of photogenerated charge carriers, resulting in an increase of CO yield by 212–fold to 265.7 mmol g–1. The selectivity was as high as 94.7% even though water was used as the sole solvent, indicating the potential application in the photocatalytic process combining H2O oxidation and CO2 reduction. The photocatalyst PolyIPN–TPY displayed good recyclability and stability during photocatalysis. More importantly, the photocatalyst PolyIPN–TPY exhibited both high CO2 adsorption and robust CO2 reduction performance, which paves a promising avenue for light–driven simultaneous capture and utilization of CO2 under mild conditions without consuming a great deal of energy. coredata.dc:description: Development of photocatalysts with both high CO2 adsorption capacity and robust CO2 reduction performance is promising toward carbon capture and utilization (CCU). Herein, a porous organic polymer (POP) based on molecular monomers 1,2,3,5–Tetrakis(carbazol–9–yl)–4,6–dicyanobenzene (4CzIPN) and 9–(4–([2,2′:6′,2′'–terpyridin]–4′–yl)phenyl)–9H–carbazole (CzTPY) has been prepared for metal–free photocatalytic reduction of CO2 to CO with 94.7% selectivity in 100% aqueous medium. The POP displays a yield of CO up to 265.7 mmol g–1, which is among the highest yields for POPs–based photocatalytic systems. More importantly, the POP also shows a high CO2 uptake of 109.1 cm3 g–1 (21.4 wt%) at 273 K and 1 atm. External photosensitizers or catalysts are not required in this photocatalytic system. Mechanistic studies indicate the introduction of CzTPY improved the electron transfer and charge separation. These results show a feasible way to construct POP–based photocatalysts not only capturing CO2 efficiently but also catalyzing CO2 reduction with a high yield by rational regulation of molecular monomers.
coredata.dc:title: A metal–free porous organic polymer with high CO2 adsorption for robust aqueous CO2 photoreduction via molecular regulation
